metadata.description: Comprehensive database of college admissions counselor perspectives, preferences, and evaluation criteria

consulting_resources.name: Admissions Madness
consulting_resources.counselor_background: Kevin Martin, former UT-Austin admissions counselor, Fulbright Fellow
consulting_resources.description: Fresh perspectives on college admissions process, challenges underlying assumptions in higher education
consulting_resources.specialty: Holistic approach to admissions, addresses student psychology and systemic issues

consulting_resources.name: College Essay Guy
consulting_resources.description: Comprehensive resources for college essays, application process, specific university guides
consulting_resources.specialty: Essay writing, personal narratives, application strategies

consulting_resources.name: Admissions.Blog (Undergraduate Admissions Uncensored)
consulting_resources.description: Uncensored analysis of admissions trends, early decision data, university-specific insights

consulting_resources.name: IvyWise
consulting_resources.counselor_background: Dr. Kat Cohen and team of admissions experts
consulting_resources.description: Comprehensive admissions guidance, financial aid strategies, college rankings analysis
consulting_resources.specialty: Ivy League and selective college admissions

consulting_resources.name: Top Tier Admissions
consulting_resources.description: Expert admissions advice, supplemental essay guides, college-specific strategies

consulting_resources.name: PrepScholar
consulting_resources.description: Detailed guides on getting into top schools, personal narratives from accepted students
consulting_resources.specialty: Academic preparation, standardized testing, Ivy League admissions

consulting_resources.name: Ivy Coach
consulting_resources.counselor_background: Team of former elite college admissions officers
consulting_resources.description: Premium admissions counseling, 90%+ acceptance rates to Harvard/Stanford for package clients
consulting_resources.specialty: Early application strategies, singular hooks, elite college admissions

consulting_resources.name: InGenius Prep
consulting_resources.counselor_background: Former admissions officers from top universities
consulting_resources.description: Podcast featuring former admissions officers discussing holistic review, decision-making

consulting_resources.name: College Transitions
consulting_resources.description: Data-driven research on college admissions, acceptance rates, trends

consulting_resources.name: Expert Admissions
consulting_resources.description: Application advice, interview preparation, demonstrated interest strategies

database_resources.name: College Board BigFuture
database_resources.description: Comprehensive college search with admission, tuition, financial aid data

database_resources.name: Common Application
database_resources.description: Platform for applying to colleges, member institutions

database_resources.name: CollegeData
database_resources.description: College search, admissions calculator, scholarship finder, Common Data Set info

database_resources.name: College Navigator (NCES)
database_resources.description: Government database with comprehensive data on all US colleges

database_resources.name: Coalition for College
database_resources.description: Member schools committed to access, affordability, and graduation

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: No formula for gaining admission. Academic accomplishment is important, but admissions committee considers community involvement, leadership, distinction in extracurricular activities, and personal qualities and character.
counselor_perspectives.holistic_review: Relies on teachers, counselors, and alumni to share information about applicant's strength of character, ability to overcome adversity, and other personal qualities.
what_they_seek: Leadership and distinction in extracurricular activities
Students who will contribute to Harvard's mission
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_process: Applications discussed after initial review, candidates must stand out beyond just good test scores and grades
counselor_perspectives.memorable_candidates: Students with clear arc to their application: notable scientist, future political leader, bridge-builder in times of division

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Top 10% of graduating class minimum (vast majority)

test_scores.testing_requirement: SAT or ACT required. In exceptional cases when not accessible: AP, IB, GCSE, or National Leaving Exams accepted

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most rigorous courses available at high school, especially strong academic record
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Academic accomplishment in high school is important but not sufficient alone

essay_requirements.supplement_questions: Five required short-answer questions, 150 word limit each
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Ensure every student has same opportunity to reflect on life experiences, academic/extracurricular activities, how they will engage with others at Harvard, aspirations for future
what_makes_strong_essays: Authenticity and genuine voice
Reflection on life experiences
How experiences shaped the applicant
Clear vision for engagement at Harvard
Future aspirations

extracurriculars.importance: Critical - distinction in extracurricular activities is key differentiator
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and distinction matter more than breadth
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership and community involvement highly valued
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Must show how activities demonstrate character and contribution to community
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Many admitted students have state or national-level recognition in their craft

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Letters from teachers, counselors, and alumni
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Harvard relies heavily on these to understand applicant beyond scores

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not explicitly stated as primary factor
demonstrated_interest.how_measured: Through essays, interviews, and engagement with Harvard community

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Discussion of each candidate after initial review, must stand out beyond academics
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Holistic review considering academics, activities, personal qualities, recommendations
evaluation_rubrics.committee_process: Applications reviewed by admissions committee, consensus-based decisions

unique_insights: Harvard admits ~3% of applicants - most competitive in nation
Students who demonstrate deep passion, grit, and work ethic have best chances
Clear narrative arc in application is crucial: the notable scientist, the future leader, the bridge-builder
Test scores and grades are baseline filters, not sufficient for admission
Many admitted students are first-generation college students from diverse backgrounds
Cross-admit data: 62% of students admitted to both Harvard and Stanford choose Harvard
When given choice between Harvard and other top schools: 65% choose Harvard over Yale, 75% choose Harvard over Princeton
common_pitfalls: Being 'just' a well-rounded student with good scores
Lacking clear passion or specialization
Not demonstrating impact or achievement beyond grades
Generic essays without authentic voice
Spreading activities too thin without depth

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: While grades and scores are important in understanding academic preparedness for MIT, it's really the match between applicant and the Institute that drives our selection process.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: MIT's mission is to use science, technology, and other areas of scholarship to make the world better. Community values excellence, openness, and fearless curiosity.

evaluation_factors.academic_preparedness: Must demonstrate readiness for fast-paced core curriculum and educational autonomy
evaluation_factors.noncognitive_indicators: Curiosity, initiative, resilience, ability to accept feedback, adaptability
evaluation_factors.character_qualities: Thoughtful people who take care of each other and lift each other up

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Top 10% of class (100% of admitted students who submitted class rank)

test_scores.testing_requirement: SAT or ACT required - reinstated after research showed need for students with least resources
test_scores.superscoring: Yes, MIT superscores both SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding courses available, especially in math and science. All students take foundational math/science regardless of major
academic_criteria.math_science_preparation: Critical - even humanities majors must take two semesters of physics

essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Show passion, alignment with MIT values, authentic voice
what_makes_strong_essays: Demonstrating hands-on experience and making
Showing collaborative spirit
Evidence of taking thoughtful risks
Balance between academics and personal interests
Quality over quantity in activities
essay_requirements.activity_description: Balance for the pleasure of it - MIT is NOT all work

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - evaluated on tier system
extracurriculars.tier_system: Tier 1 (exceptional, specialized like conducting prize-winning independent research) most competitive
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Quality over quantity - don't expect million things. Put heart into few things you truly care about
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Students apply theoretical knowledge to real-world problems, must show hands-on engagement
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Impact doesn't require curing diseases - tutoring a kid in math changes the world, advocating for change matters
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Hands-on makers, students who get 'metaphorically or literally' dirty trying something new

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: One from math/science teacher, one from humanities/social sciences/languages teacher
what_reviewers_look_for: Recent teacher who knows student well and likes them
Specific examples of achievements and contributions
Genuine insights into who student truly is
letters_of_recommendation.supplemental_recommendations: Not advised if from someone well-known but doesn't really know the student

demonstrated_interest.importance: Lower priority than fit and match
demonstrated_interest.interviews: MIT tries to interview all applicants with ~5,500 alumni interviewers, but not required. No campus interviews

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Application read by senior admissions officer holistically, strong applications read by additional officers who summarize for Admissions Committee
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: At least a dozen people significantly discuss and debate an application before admit pile
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Multiple groups of different admissions staff and faculty weigh in
key_evaluation_points: Match with MIT culture and mission

unique_insights: MIT's Latin motto 'Mens et Manus' (Mind and Hand) reflects hands-on philosophy
Innovation is risky and messy - MIT values students who embrace this
Community values are critical: thoughtful people who lift each other up
Reinstated testing requirement based on equity research - helps students with least resources demonstrate preparation
Students regularly work alongside faculty to shape MIT policies
Risk-taking can lead to failure, but structural supports help students learn resilience
MIT has active blogs since 2004, unfiltered student narratives
common_pitfalls: Focusing solely on academic achievement without showing hands-on making
Not demonstrating collaborative spirit or community care
Appearing to do activities just for resume building
Lacking balance between work and personal interests
Not showing resilience or willingness to take risks
Focusing on breadth over depth in activities

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Stanford seeks students who will make meaningful contributions to the Stanford community and, eventually, to the world. We look for distinctive students who exhibit an abundance of energy and curiosity in their classes, activities, projects, research, and lives.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Stanford's commitment to access, opportunity, and impact drives admissions. The university values intellectual vitality, demonstrated impact, and distinctive perspective.
what_they_seek: Intellectual vitality - love of learning for its own sake
Evidence of initiative and impact beyond the classroom
Students who will contribute to Stanford's mission of creating knowledge and educating students
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Stanford employs comprehensive holistic review. Essays are weighted very heavily - they want to understand who you are beyond test scores and grades. They seek students who show depth of thought, reflection, and authentic voice.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Most admitted students are in top 10% of their class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.testing_requirement: Test-optional for recent cycles, but strong scores still advantageous

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding curriculum available - expects maximum challenge in areas of strength. Values depth in academic interests.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values students who pursue learning beyond classroom requirements - independent research, advanced coursework, intellectual exploration

essay_requirements.personal_statement: Common Application or Coalition Application essay
essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple short essays including 'What matters to you and why?' (100-250 words) and 'Why Stanford?' essays
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Essays are critically important at Stanford. They want authentic, distinctive, memorable voices. Essays reveal intellectual vitality, values, perspective, and fit with Stanford's culture.
what_makes_strong_essays: Authentic voice that sounds like a real person, not polished to perfection
Specific, vivid examples and storytelling
Deep reflection and self-awareness
Demonstrating intellectual vitality and curiosity
Showing your unique perspective and values
Genuine enthusiasm for Stanford's specific offerings
Avoiding clichés and generic statements
Demonstrating impact and initiative
common_essay_mistakes: Essays that sound too polished or written by committee
Generic 'Why Stanford' essays listing famous programs without personal connection
Trying to be who you think Stanford wants rather than being yourself
Lists of accomplishments without reflection
Lack of specificity or concrete examples

extracurriculars.importance: Extremely high - Stanford looks for sustained impact and depth
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Strongly prefer depth and distinction over breadth. Quality of impact matters far more than quantity of activities.
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership and initiative are valued, but formal titles less important than demonstrated impact
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Must show tangible impact - what changed because of your involvement? Numbers, outcomes, and sustained commitment matter.
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Many admitted students have regional, state, or national recognition, but impact can also be deeply local
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Innovation, entrepreneurship, creative problem-solving, and making things happen

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations (from different subject areas) plus counselor recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Intellectual vitality and curiosity in classroom
Contribution to class discussions and community
How student stands out among peers
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Very important - strong letters can significantly boost application

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not tracked - Stanford does not consider demonstrated interest
demonstrated_interest.interviews: Optional interviews with alumni when available, not required or guaranteed

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Multiple readers review each application. First read by regional officer, strong applications get second and third reads, then committee discussion for competitive applicants.
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Final decisions made in committee with multiple admissions officers discussing each case
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Holistic evaluation of academic excellence, intellectual vitality, personal context, extracurricular impact, and fit with Stanford mission
key_evaluation_points: Academic excellence and preparation for Stanford's rigor
Intellectual vitality - genuine love of learning
Essay quality - distinctive voice and perspective
Recommendations - evidence of classroom contribution and character
Contribution to Stanford community - what will you add?

unique_insights: Stanford places exceptional weight on essays - they truly want to hear your voice
Intellectual vitality is Stanford's signature evaluation criterion - showing you love learning for its own sake
Location in Silicon Valley shapes culture - innovation and entrepreneurship highly valued
Stanford looks for students who will 'make a difference' - impact orientation is key
The 'What matters to you and why?' essay is uniquely Stanford - reveals values and depth of thought
Stanford has one of lowest acceptance rates (~3.7%) but seeks accessible, authentic students, not perfection
Cross-admit data: 38% choose Stanford over Harvard - strong preference among STEM/innovation-focused students
Stanford values diversity of thought and experience - geographic, socioeconomic, and intellectual diversity all matter
common_pitfalls: Generic or overly polished essays that lack authentic voice
Not demonstrating intellectual vitality beyond grades and test scores
Shallow involvement in many activities without meaningful impact
Weak 'Why Stanford' essays that could apply to any top university
Missing opportunities to show initiative and innovation
Focusing on prestige of activities rather than personal growth and impact
Trying to present a 'perfect' image rather than authentic self
Not contextualizing achievements within available opportunities
red_flags: Lack of genuine intellectual curiosity
Resume padding - long lists of brief involvements
Essays that sound like marketing materials
No evidence of impact or initiative
Inconsistencies between different parts of application
Lack of authenticity or self-awareness

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Yale undertakes a holistic review of every application. We look at academic achievement in the context of opportunities available and the student's personal story. We're building a diverse community of exceptional individuals who will learn from one another.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Yale seeks students who will take advantage of Yale's extraordinary resources and contribute to the residential college community. The university values intellectual curiosity, especially in humanities and liberal arts, along with leadership and character.
what_they_seek: Intellectual curiosity and love of learning
Students who will thrive in residential college system
Depth in academic and extracurricular pursuits
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Yale has reinstated testing requirements, viewing standardized tests as one tool to evaluate preparation. They emphasize context - what opportunities were available to you? How did you make the most of them? The committee seeks students who show both achievement and promise.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Vast majority of admitted students are in top 10% of graduating class, typically 3.95+ unweighted GPA

test_scores.testing_requirement: SAT or ACT required (reinstated after test-optional period)
test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Yale superscores both SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding curriculum available at your high school. Yale expects students to challenge themselves with honors, AP, IB, or equivalent courses.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Strong preference for students with intellectual curiosity across disciplines - the liberal arts ideal

essay_requirements.personal_statement: Common Application or Coalition Application essay (650 words)
essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Yale-specific short answer questions and essays including 'Why Yale?' and intellectual engagement questions
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Yale wants to understand who you are beyond your transcript. Essays should reveal your voice, values, intellectual interests, and how you think. They value authenticity, reflection, and specific examples.
what_makes_strong_essays: Authentic voice and genuine reflection
Specific examples and vivid storytelling
Intellectual curiosity and depth of thought
Understanding of Yale's specific offerings (residential colleges, shopping period, etc.)
Personal growth and self-awareness
How you'll contribute to Yale community
Evidence of character and values
common_essay_mistakes: Generic essays that could apply to any Ivy League school
Listing accomplishments without reflection
Overly formal or trying too hard to impress
Not demonstrating knowledge of Yale's unique features
Lack of specific examples
Missing opportunities to show intellectual curiosity

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Yale evaluates both achievement and contribution to community
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth, commitment, and impact strongly preferred over long lists of activities
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership valued, but can take many forms - formal positions, informal influence, or initiative
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Show sustained commitment and tangible outcomes. What changed because of your involvement?
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Many admitted students have state or national recognition, but deep local impact also valued
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Activities that demonstrate intellectual curiosity, service to others, and contribution to community

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation; third teacher recommendation optional
what_reviewers_look_for: Intellectual curiosity and contribution to classroom
How student interacts with peers and teachers
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Critical - Yale places heavy weight on recommendations to understand classroom presence and character

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not considered - Yale does not track demonstrated interest
demonstrated_interest.interviews: Alumni interviews offered when available, evaluative but not required. No campus interviews.

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications read by at least two admissions officers. Strong applications discussed in regional and full committee meetings.
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Admissions committee includes admissions officers and faculty. Decisions made by consensus after thorough discussion.
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Holistic evaluation considering academic achievement, testing, recommendations, essays, extracurriculars, and personal context
key_evaluation_points: Academic achievement in context of opportunities

unique_insights: Yale's residential college system is central to student life - admissions looks for students who will thrive in close-knit community
Humanities and liberal arts orientation - Yale values intellectual breadth and curiosity across disciplines
Shopping period (first two weeks to sample classes) reflects commitment to academic exploration
Yale has reinstated standardized testing requirement, viewing tests as important evaluation tool
Strong preference for students with intellectual engagement beyond classroom
Cross-admit data: 65% choose Harvard over Yale, 54% choose Yale over Stanford
Yale's location in New Haven and commitment to community engagement shapes admissions priorities
Faculty involvement in admissions decisions reflects academic focus
common_pitfalls: Not understanding Yale's distinctive features (residential colleges, shopping period, etc.)
Weak 'Why Yale?' essays without specific knowledge
Overemphasis on STEM without showing liberal arts engagement
Activity lists focused on quantity over quality
Generic essays lacking personal voice
Not demonstrating intellectual curiosity beyond grades
Missing opportunities to show character and values
Underestimating importance of standardized tests
red_flags: Below 25th percentile test scores without exceptional circumstances
Lack of intellectual curiosity or engagement
Generic application without Yale-specific knowledge
Resume padding without meaningful commitment
Essays that don't reveal authentic voice
Weak or generic recommendations

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Princeton conducts a thorough holistic review of every application. We seek students who have made the most of their opportunities and will contribute to Princeton's undergraduate-focused community. Character matters as much as achievement.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Princeton's commitment to undergraduate education is unparalleled. The university seeks students who will take advantage of independent work, junior papers, and senior thesis while contributing to tight-knit residential community.
what_they_seek: Students who will thrive with undergraduate focus and close faculty relationships
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Princeton emphasizes fit with undergraduate-focused mission. The admissions committee looks for students who will excel in Princeton's distinctive academic structure (independent work, precepts) and contribute to residential college community.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Nearly all admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Princeton superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most rigorous curriculum available. Princeton expects maximum academic challenge and depth in areas of interest.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values students prepared for independent work and research. Intellectual independence is key.

essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Princeton supplements including essays on extracurriculars, summer experiences, 'favorite' prompts, and academic interests
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Princeton values authentic voice, reflection, and insight into character. Essays should reveal intellectual curiosity, values, and how you think. The admissions committee wants to understand who you are and how you'll contribute.
what_makes_strong_essays: Authentic personal voice
Specific examples and concrete details
Reflection and self-awareness
Intellectual depth and curiosity
Understanding of Princeton's unique features (independent work, precepts, residential colleges)
Evidence of character and values
Genuine enthusiasm for Princeton's offerings
How you'll contribute to community
common_essay_mistakes: Generic 'Why Princeton' without specific knowledge
Lists of accomplishments without reflection
Trying to sound impressive rather than authentic
Missing opportunities to show character
Not demonstrating understanding of independent work or undergraduate focus
Lack of specific examples

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Princeton evaluates depth of commitment and impact
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Strongly prefer sustained depth and measurable impact over breadth
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership important, but quality of contribution matters more than titles
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Show sustained commitment over time and tangible outcomes. What impact did you make?
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Many admitted students have regional or national recognition, but deep local leadership also valued
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Service, research, intellectual pursuits, and activities showing independent initiative

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Specific examples of impact and growth
Potential for independent work and research
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Critical - Princeton places heavy emphasis on recommendations to understand character and classroom presence

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not tracked - Princeton does not consider demonstrated interest
demonstrated_interest.interviews: Alumni interviews offered when available but not required

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Each application read by multiple officers. Regional discussions followed by full committee review for competitive applicants.
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Full admissions committee discusses competitive applications. Dean of Admission makes final decisions with committee input.
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Holistic evaluation of academic achievement, personal character, extracurricular impact, and fit with Princeton's mission
key_evaluation_points: Academic excellence and preparation for rigorous curriculum
Potential for independent work and research

unique_insights: Princeton's undergraduate focus is distinctive - no professional schools competing for resources
Independent work (junior papers, senior thesis) is required for all students - admissions looks for research potential
Precept system (small discussion seminars) means classroom participation is critical
Residential college system provides tight-knit community - admissions seeks students who will contribute
Princeton's financial aid is among most generous - no loans in aid packages
Strong emphasis on public service - Pace Center and service opportunities shape campus culture
Dean's blog posts offer insights into admissions philosophy and process
Cross-admit data: 75% choose Harvard over Princeton, 74% choose Stanford over Princeton
common_pitfalls: Not understanding Princeton's distinctive features (independent work, undergraduate focus, precepts)
Weak essays without authentic voice or reflection
Not demonstrating research potential or intellectual independence
Activity lists without depth or sustained commitment
Generic 'Why Princeton' essays
Missing opportunities to show character and ethical commitment
Underestimating importance of teacher recommendations
Not conveying fit with residential community
red_flags: Lack of intellectual independence or curiosity
Shallow extracurricular involvement
Generic essays without Princeton-specific knowledge
Below 25th percentile scores without compelling story
Weak character recommendations
No evidence of research interest or independent thinking

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Columbia seeks students who are ready to engage with the Core Curriculum and New York City. We look for intellectual curiosity, engagement with big ideas, and students who will thrive in our unique urban environment while building community.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Columbia's Core Curriculum requires all students to engage with foundational texts in literature, philosophy, science, and the arts. Admissions seeks students excited by this rigorous common intellectual experience and ready to contribute to classroom discussions.
what_they_seek: Intellectual engagement with big ideas and texts
Readiness for Core Curriculum's intensive reading and discussion
Students who will engage with NYC as an extension of campus
Diverse perspectives to enrich Core discussions
Students who thrive in structured academic environment
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Columbia's holistic review emphasizes fit with the Core Curriculum and urban campus. They seek students who will actively engage in seminar-style classes and take advantage of NYC's cultural and intellectual resources.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Nearly all admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.testing_requirement: Test-flexible policy - can submit SAT, ACT, or three AP exam scores
test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Columbia superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding curriculum available. Strong preparation in humanities, sciences, and mathematics expected for Core success.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values intellectual breadth - Core requires engagement across disciplines

essay_requirements.personal_statement: Common Application or Coalition Application essay (650 words)
essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Columbia supplements including 'Why Columbia?' and intellectual interest questions; separate essays for Columbia College vs. Engineering
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Columbia wants to see genuine intellectual curiosity and specific understanding of the Core Curriculum and NYC location. Essays should demonstrate readiness for rigorous academic community and urban environment.
what_makes_strong_essays: Specific knowledge of Core Curriculum and genuine enthusiasm for it
Understanding of how NYC enhances education
Intellectual depth and engagement with ideas
Specific courses, professors, or programs at Columbia
How you'll contribute to classroom discussions
Balance between intellectual pursuits and community engagement
Authentic voice and reflection
common_essay_mistakes: Generic 'Why Columbia' without mentioning Core Curriculum
Focusing only on NYC location without academic substance
Not understanding what Core Curriculum actually entails
Missing opportunities to show intellectual engagement
Weak Columbia College vs. Engineering school differentiation
Listing famous programs without personal connection

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Columbia evaluates leadership and impact
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and sustained commitment preferred over breadth
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership valued, including intellectual leadership and initiative
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Show sustained involvement and measurable outcomes
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Mix of highly recognized achievements and deep local impact
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Civic engagement, urban-focused activities, intellectual pursuits, activities showing engagement with diverse communities

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Contribution to classroom discussions (crucial for Core success)
Intellectual curiosity and engagement with ideas
Ability to work with diverse perspectives
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Critical - recommendations should demonstrate readiness for discussion-based Core classes

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not officially tracked, but 'Why Columbia' essay must show genuine knowledge
demonstrated_interest.interviews: Alumni interviews offered when available but not required

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications reviewed by multiple readers. Strong applications discussed in committee.
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Admissions committee makes decisions after holistic review and discussion
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Evaluation based on academic achievement, fit with Core Curriculum, extracurricular impact, essays, and recommendations
key_evaluation_points: Academic preparation for rigorous Core Curriculum
Intellectual curiosity and engagement with big ideas
Potential to thrive in NYC urban environment

unique_insights: Core Curriculum is defining feature - all students read same foundational texts, engage in seminars
NYC location is both campus and classroom - Columbia seeks students who will engage with city
Urban campus requires students to build community intentionally - different from traditional campuses
Test-flexible policy allows three AP scores instead of SAT/ACT
Columbia College focuses on liberal arts, Engineering school (SEAS) on applied science
Competition is intense - one of lowest acceptance rates among Ivies (~3.9%)
Strong emphasis on civic engagement and public service
Location near Harlem and partnership with community shapes institutional values
common_pitfalls: Not understanding or mentioning Core Curriculum in application
Treating NYC as a tourist attraction rather than educational resource
Generic essays that could apply to any urban university
Not differentiating between Columbia College and Engineering school
Missing opportunities to show intellectual engagement with texts and ideas
Underestimating importance of classroom discussion skills
Not demonstrating community-building in urban context
Weak understanding of Columbia's specific academic structure
red_flags: No mention of Core Curriculum or misunderstanding what it is
Lack of intellectual curiosity or engagement with ideas
Generic application without Columbia-specific knowledge
Recommendations that don't show classroom participation
Essays focused only on location/prestige without academic substance
Shallow extracurricular involvement

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Penn seeks students who demonstrate passion for learning, commitment to their community, and desire to make an impact. We value the integration of knowledge across disciplines and putting theory into practice.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Penn's focus on interdisciplinary learning and practical application drives admissions. The university values students who cross traditional boundaries between disciplines and connect classroom learning to real-world impact.
what_they_seek: Practical application of knowledge - 'theory and practice'
Students who will take advantage of Penn's resources across four undergraduate schools
Pre-professional mindset combined with liberal arts foundation
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Penn's holistic review emphasizes fit with specific undergraduate school (College, Wharton, Engineering, Nursing) while valuing interdisciplinary exploration. Demonstrated interest in Penn's unique offerings is important.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Most admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Penn superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most rigorous curriculum available. Expectations vary by school - Wharton and Engineering expect strong quantitative preparation.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values interdisciplinary interests and ability to cross traditional academic boundaries

essay_requirements.personal_statement: Common Application or Coalition Application essay (650 words)
essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Penn supplements including school-specific essays for each undergraduate school, 'Why Penn?' essay, and additional short answers
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Penn wants to see specific knowledge of the university's offerings and genuine enthusiasm. Essays should demonstrate interdisciplinary thinking, practical application mindset, and fit with specific undergraduate school.
what_makes_strong_essays: Specific Penn programs, courses, professors, or opportunities mentioned
Understanding of interdisciplinary resources (dual degrees, minors, coordinated programs)
Clear fit with specific undergraduate school (College, Wharton, Engineering, Nursing)
How you'll connect theory to practice
Genuine passion and clear academic/career interests
Understanding of Penn's urban Ivy character
Specific ways you'll engage with Philadelphia community
Interdisciplinary interests and connections
common_essay_mistakes: Generic 'Why Penn' without specific programs or resources
Not differentiating between undergraduate schools
Missing interdisciplinary opportunities in essays
Weak Wharton essays that don't show business interest foundation
Not connecting classroom learning to real-world application
Ignoring Philadelphia location and community engagement
Listing famous programs without personal connection

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Penn evaluates both achievement and practical application
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and sustained leadership strongly preferred
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership highly valued, especially showing initiative and impact
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Must show tangible outcomes and sustained commitment. Penn values practical application of interests.
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Mix of high-level recognition and deep community impact
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Business/entrepreneurship, community engagement, interdisciplinary projects, activities showing real-world application of knowledge

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Specific examples of impact and achievement
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Very important - strong recommendations can significantly boost application

demonstrated_interest.importance: Considered - Penn values genuine interest demonstrated through campus visits, essays, and engagement
demonstrated_interest.interviews: Alumni interviews strongly encouraged when available, evaluative

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications read by regional officers, strong applications get multiple reads and committee discussion
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Admissions committee makes final decisions after holistic review
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Evaluation based on academic achievement, school-specific fit, interdisciplinary interests, extracurricular impact, and demonstrated interest
key_evaluation_points: Academic excellence and preparation for rigorous curriculum
Recommendations showing classroom excellence and character

unique_insights: Penn is 'urban Ivy' - engaged with Philadelphia community and city resources
Four undergraduate schools require different preparation: College (liberal arts), Wharton (business), Engineering, Nursing
Interdisciplinary opportunities are exceptional - dual degrees, coordinated programs, minors across schools
Pre-professional culture stronger than other Ivies - practical application valued
Benjamin Franklin's vision of practical education still shapes institutional culture
Strong entrepreneurship ecosystem and business mindset across schools
Demonstrated interest matters more at Penn than some other top schools
Wharton is world's top undergraduate business program - extremely competitive
Penn has highest percentage of international students among Ivies
common_pitfalls: Not understanding differences between Penn's four undergraduate schools
Weak 'Why Penn' essays without specific knowledge
Missing Penn's interdisciplinary strengths in application
Not demonstrating genuine interest through essays and engagement
Wharton applicants without clear business interest or foundation
Ignoring Philadelphia location and community engagement opportunities
Generic essays that could apply to any Ivy
Not showing practical application mindset
Underestimating importance of alumni interview
red_flags: Lack of specific knowledge about Penn's programs and resources
No clear fit with chosen undergraduate school
Missing interdisciplinary interests
Weak demonstrated interest
Generic application without Penn-specific research
Wharton applicants with no business/economics background
Shallow extracurricular involvement

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Duke seeks students who are curious, collaborative, and committed to making a positive impact. We look for students who will engage deeply with their education, contribute to our vibrant community, and connect learning with purpose.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Duke's focus on 'knowledge in service to society' drives admissions. The university values students who combine academic excellence with community engagement and demonstrate how they'll use their Duke education to make a difference.
what_they_seek: Connecting learning with purpose - 'knowledge in service to society'
Students who will engage with DukeEngage and service opportunities
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Duke's holistic review emphasizes both achievement and character. They seek students who show intellectual vitality, commitment to others, and desire to make positive impact.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Most admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Duke superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding curriculum available. Duke expects strong preparation across disciplines.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values interdisciplinary interests - students explore across Trinity College of Arts & Sciences and Pratt School of Engineering

essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Duke supplements including 'Why Duke?' and prompts about community, learning, and purpose
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Duke wants to see genuine connection between your interests and Duke's mission. Essays should demonstrate understanding of 'knowledge in service to society' and how you'll contribute to collaborative community.
what_makes_strong_essays: Specific Duke programs and opportunities (DukeEngage, Bass Connections, etc.)
Understanding of service and impact orientation
How you connect learning with purpose
Genuine enthusiasm for Duke's collaborative culture
Balance between achievement and character
Specific examples of community engagement
Understanding of Trinity vs. Pratt (Engineering)
Authentic voice and reflection
common_essay_mistakes: Generic 'Why Duke' without specific programs
Not mentioning service or community engagement
Missing Duke's 'knowledge in service to society' mission
Weak differentiation between Trinity and Pratt
Focusing only on basketball/campus beauty without academic substance
Not demonstrating collaborative spirit
Listing programs without personal connection

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Duke evaluates leadership, service, and impact
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and sustained commitment strongly preferred
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership highly valued, especially in service-oriented activities
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Must show tangible impact on community. Service and engagement are central to Duke's mission.
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Mix of high-level achievement and deep community service
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Service and community engagement, collaborative projects, activities connecting learning with impact

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation; optional additional recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Collaborative spirit and relationship with peers
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Very important - character and community engagement should come through in recommendations

demonstrated_interest.interviews: Alumni interviews offered when available, strongly encouraged

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications read by regional admissions officers, strong applications discussed in committee
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Full committee review for competitive applicants
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Holistic evaluation of academic achievement, character, service, leadership, and fit with Duke's mission

unique_insights: DukeEngage provides funded summer service experiences globally - admissions looks for service-oriented students
Bass Connections links faculty and students across disciplines for research on societal challenges
Trinity College (Arts & Sciences) and Pratt School (Engineering) have different cultures but shared values
Durham location and community engagement are important - Duke partners with local community
Balance between academic excellence and strong athletics/spirit (Cameron Crazies, Duke basketball)
'Knowledge in service to society' is not just motto - it shapes curriculum and student culture
Robertson Scholars Program (Duke-UNC partnership) attracts top students committed to public service
Gothic architecture and campus beauty mentioned by many students, but substance matters more than aesthetics in admissions
common_pitfalls: Not demonstrating service orientation or community engagement
Weak 'Why Duke' without mentioning service mission or specific programs
Focusing on basketball/sports culture without academic substance
Missing connection between learning and purpose
Generic essays that could apply to any top university
Not understanding Trinity vs. Pratt differences
Shallow community service without genuine commitment
Underestimating importance of character and collaboration
red_flags: No evidence of service or community engagement
Lack of specific Duke knowledge in application
Generic application without connection to Duke's mission
Recommendations that don't show character or collaborative spirit
Essays focused only on prestige/rankings without understanding values
Shallow extracurricular involvement

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: UChicago seeks students who love learning for its own sake and will thrive in our intense intellectual community. We value unconventional thinkers who engage deeply with ideas and aren't afraid to challenge assumptions. The essay is where we see if you'll fit with our 'life of the mind' culture.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: UChicago's 'life of the mind' philosophy permeates everything. The university seeks students who are intellectually curious, willing to engage in rigorous debate, comfortable with ambiguity, and excited by ideas themselves - not just their applications.
what_they_seek: Deep intellectual curiosity - 'life of the mind'
Unconventional thinking and willingness to challenge ideas
Love of learning for learning's sake
Engagement with big questions and abstract concepts
Students who thrive on debate and discussion
Comfort with intensity and intellectual challenge
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: UChicago's essays are legendarily unique and quirky - they're designed to identify students who will engage with UChicago's intellectual intensity. The admissions committee wants to see creative, thoughtful responses that reveal how you think, not just what you've achieved.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Most admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.superscoring: Yes, UChicago superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding curriculum available. UChicago expects serious academic preparation and intellectual rigor.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values deep engagement with ideas across disciplines. Core Curriculum requires breadth of study.

essay_requirements.personal_statement: Common Application or Coalition Application essay (650 words)
essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Extended essay responding to one of UChicago's unique prompts (can be from current year or past prompts), plus 'Why UChicago?' and other short responses
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: UChicago's essays are famous for being quirky, unconventional, and intellectually challenging. They want to see creative thinking, intellectual playfulness, deep engagement with ideas, and authentic voice. The extended essay is the heart of the application.
what_makes_strong_essays: Intellectual creativity and original thinking
Deep engagement with the prompt - not superficial treatment
Authentic voice - being genuinely yourself, even if quirky
Intellectual playfulness and willingness to take creative risks
Demonstrating how you think, not just what you know
Love of ideas and learning for their own sake
Specific understanding of UChicago's 'life of the mind' culture
Comfort with ambiguity and complexity
unique_essay_prompts_examples: Find X (past prompt - can involve math, philosophy, treasure hunts, variables)
What's so odd about odd numbers?
Due to a series of clerical errors, there is exactly one typo in the name of every department at UChicago...

The mantis shrimp can perceive both polarized light and multispectral images; they have the most complex eyes in the animal kingdom. Human eyes have color receptors for three colors... What might we be missing, and what are we missing out on?
Joan of Arkansas. Queen Elizabeth Cady Stanton. Babe Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Mash up a historical figure with a new time period, environment, location, or occupation, and tell us their story.
common_essay_mistakes: Treating unique prompts as standard college essays
Being too safe or conventional in response to creative prompts
Not showing genuine intellectual curiosity
Generic 'Why UChicago' without understanding 'life of the mind'
Trying to sound smart rather than being authentic
Surface-level engagement with deep prompts
Missing opportunities to show intellectual playfulness
Not understanding UChicago's quirky, intense culture

extracurriculars.importance: High, but less emphasized than intellectual curiosity and essays
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and intellectual engagement matter more than impressive titles
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership valued but intellectual leadership and independent pursuits equally important
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Impact matters, but intellectual pursuits and genuine interests valued over resume building
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Mix of recognition and deep intellectual engagement
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Intellectual activities, research, debate, academic competitions, quirky independent projects, activities showing genuine curiosity

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Intellectual curiosity and love of learning
Contribution to classroom discussions and debate
Ability to engage with complex ideas
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Very important - should demonstrate intellectual engagement and 'life of the mind' qualities

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not tracked - UChicago doesn't consider demonstrated interest
demonstrated_interest.interviews: Optional interviews with alumni when available

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications read by multiple officers with heavy emphasis on essays. Extended essay is critical differentiator.
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Committee discusses competitive applications, with essays playing central role in decisions
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Holistic review with exceptional weight on essay quality, intellectual curiosity, and fit with UChicago's intense academic culture
key_evaluation_points: Essay quality - creativity, depth, authentic voice
Intellectual curiosity and love of learning
Fit with 'life of the mind' culture
Academic preparation for rigorous Core Curriculum
Ability to engage with complex ideas

unique_insights: UChicago's extended essay prompts are legendary - quirky, intellectual, designed to find unconventional thinkers
'Where fun comes to die' is a self-aware joke about academic intensity - students are seriously intellectual
Core Curriculum is one of most rigorous - extensive requirements in humanities, sciences, social sciences
Scav Hunt (annual scavenger hunt) exemplifies combination of intellectual intensity and playfulness
House system provides community within intense academic environment
Location in Hyde Park, Chicago provides urban resources while maintaining campus community
UChicago students genuinely enjoy intellectual debate and learning - not just grade-focused
The essay is the most important part of the application - shows if you'll thrive in UChicago's unique culture
common_pitfalls: Safe, conventional essays that don't engage with UChicago's quirky prompts
Not understanding or embracing 'life of the mind' culture
Generic 'Why UChicago' essays
Treating extended essay as typical college essay
Not showing genuine love of learning and ideas
Trying to appear perfect rather than authentic and quirky
Missing intellectual playfulness in essays
Not demonstrating fit with intense academic culture
Underestimating importance of creative, thoughtful essay responses
red_flags: Generic or superficial extended essay responses
No evidence of intellectual curiosity beyond grades
Essays that don't show authentic voice or creative thinking
Missing understanding of UChicago's distinctive culture
Lack of engagement with ideas for their own sake
Too focused on practical applications without intellectual foundation
Conventional thinking without questioning assumptions

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Northwestern seeks students who are intellectually curious, ambitious, and collaborative. We value students who pursue their passions with purpose and will take advantage of our unique combination of academic rigor, pre-professional opportunities, and Big Ten spirit.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Northwestern combines academic excellence with practical, pre-professional focus. The university values students who integrate learning across disciplines, engage with real-world applications, and contribute to vibrant campus community.
what_they_seek: Clear passions and sense of purpose
Pre-professional ambition combined with liberal arts foundation
Students who will engage across Northwestern's schools and programs
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Northwestern's holistic review emphasizes fit with specific undergraduate school while valuing interdisciplinary exploration. The university seeks students who show both focused passion and breadth of interests.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Most admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Northwestern superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding curriculum available. Expectations vary by school - Engineering (McCormick) expects strong STEM preparation, Journalism (Medill) expects writing/communication background.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values focused interests combined with interdisciplinary exploration

essay_requirements.personal_statement: Common Application or Coalition Application essay (650 words)
essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Northwestern supplements including 'Why Northwestern?' and school-specific questions for each undergraduate school
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Northwestern wants to see specific knowledge of the university's offerings and genuine fit with chosen school. Essays should demonstrate clear academic interests, understanding of interdisciplinary opportunities, and excitement about Northwestern's unique combination of rigor and spirit.
what_makes_strong_essays: Specific Northwestern programs, courses, or opportunities
Understanding of chosen undergraduate school's unique features
How you'll take advantage of interdisciplinary resources
Balance of academic focus and campus engagement
Genuine enthusiasm for Northwestern's culture
Clear academic and career goals
Understanding of quarter system and its benefits
Connection to Chicago location and opportunities
common_essay_mistakes: Generic 'Why Northwestern' without specific programs
Not differentiating between Northwestern's six undergraduate schools
Missing interdisciplinary opportunities
Focusing only on location or rankings without academic substance
Weak school-specific essays (especially for Medill, McCormick, or Bienen)
Not showing understanding of quarter system
Listing famous programs without personal connection

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Northwestern evaluates depth, leadership, and passion
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and leadership strongly preferred, but Northwestern also values well-roundedness
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Must show sustained commitment and measurable impact
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Mix of high-level achievement and deep engagement
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Pre-professional activities (journalism, business, theater, music), research, community engagement, activities aligned with chosen school

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: One counselor recommendation plus one teacher recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Specific examples of achievement and impact
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Important - should support academic excellence and character

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not officially tracked, but 'Why Northwestern' essay must show genuine knowledge and interest

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications read by regional admissions officers, strong applications discussed in committee
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Committee makes decisions after holistic review
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Evaluation based on academic achievement, school-specific fit, extracurricular depth, essays, and recommendations

undergraduate_schools.weinberg_college: College of Arts and Sciences - liberal arts foundation
undergraduate_schools.mccormick_engineering: Engineering and Applied Science - requires strong STEM background
undergraduate_schools.medill_journalism: Journalism, Media, Integrated Marketing Communications - highly selective, requires demonstrated interest in journalism/communications
undergraduate_schools.bienen_music: Music school - requires audition, combines conservatory training with liberal arts
undergraduate_schools.communication: School of Communication - theater, performance, communication studies
undergraduate_schools.education_social_policy: School of Education and Social Policy - smaller, specialized programs

unique_insights: Northwestern combines academic rigor of top university with Big Ten athletics and school spirit
Six undergraduate schools offer pre-professional focus unusual for research university
Medill School of Journalism is one of best in world - extremely competitive and requires clear journalism interest
Quarter system (three 10-week quarters) allows students to take more courses and explore broadly
Location in Evanston provides both campus community and easy access to Chicago
Strong theater and performance programs attract creative, talented students
Interdisciplinary opportunities - many students pursue dual degrees or minors across schools
Collaborative rather than cutthroat culture despite academic rigor
NU alumni network is particularly strong and engaged
Balance of academic excellence, pre-professional opportunities, and traditional college experience
common_pitfalls: Not understanding differences between Northwestern's six undergraduate schools
Weak 'Why Northwestern' without specific programs or knowledge
Missing Northwestern's unique combination of rigor and spirit
Not demonstrating clear fit with chosen school
Generic essays that could apply to any top university
Medill applicants without demonstrated journalism/communications interest
McCormick (Engineering) applicants without strong STEM background
Ignoring quarter system and its implications
Not showing understanding of interdisciplinary opportunities
Underestimating competitiveness of specific schools (especially Medill)
red_flags: Lack of specific Northwestern knowledge in essays
No clear fit with chosen undergraduate school
Medill applicants with no journalism/communications background
McCormick applicants with weak STEM preparation
Generic application without school-specific research
Missing understanding of Northwestern's distinctive culture
Shallow extracurricular involvement

tier_1_highly_selective.description: Acceptance rates 5-10%, requires comprehensive deep research

universities.name: Cornell University
universities.specialty: Largest Ivy, diverse schools, received 72,519 applications for Class of 2029

tier_2_very_selective.description: Acceptance rates 10-20%, important for comprehensive database

universities.name: University of Southern California (USC)
universities.specialty: Film school, West Coast private, 42,000 Early Action applications

universities.name: New York University (NYU)
universities.specialty: Urban campus, 120,633 applications for Class of 2029 (record-breaking)

universities.name: University of Michigan
universities.specialty: Public Ivy, ~109,000 applications (record), strong all around

tier_3_selective_liberal_arts.description: Top liberal arts colleges, acceptance rates 10-20%

universities.name: University of North Carolina - Chapel Hill

tier_5_uc_system.description: University of California system schools with unique admissions process
tier_5_uc_system.note: UC applications have unique essay approach (PIQs), Common App deadline December 1
uc_specific_research_needed: Personal Insight Questions (PIQs) vs Common App essays
Holistic review specific to UC system
How each UC campus differs in priorities

tier_6_state_flagships.description: Major state universities with varying selectivity

next_steps_for_expansion: Complete deep research on Columbia, Penn, Duke, UChicago, Northwestern (Priority 2)
Begin systematic research on Tier 1 highly selective (Caltech, Brown, Dartmouth, etc.)
Expand to Tier 2 very selective universities
Map out UC system specific admissions criteria
Include state flagship universities for comprehensive coverage

common_themes_across_top_universities: Holistic review is universal - academics alone insufficient
Demonstrated passion and depth matter more than breadth
Impact and contribution to community highly valued
Letters of recommendation from people who truly know applicant
Most want students who will contribute to their specific mission/culture
Testing requirements being reinstated at many schools after brief test-optional period
differentiators_between_schools: MIT: Hands-on makers, 'Mens et Manus', collaborative spirit, STEM preparation
Harvard: Clear narrative arc, world-class achievement, leadership
Stanford: Intellectual ethos, essays weighted heavily, innovation focus
Princeton: Undergraduate focus, particularly competitive for STEM/policy
Each school has unique culture that drives evaluation
evaluation_processes: At least dozen people discuss applications at MIT
Holistic review considers context of opportunities available
Interviews where available provide additional data points

scoring_framework_considerations: Academic strength (GPA, test scores, rigor) - baseline filter
Depth and impact of extracurriculars - major differentiator
Quality of essays and authentic voice - critical for top schools
Letters of recommendation strength - reveals character
Alignment with specific university culture/mission - fit assessment
Demonstrated leadership and community contribution - values alignment
Overcoming adversity and resilience - personal qualities
Unique hook or distinguishing characteristic - memorability
common_weaknesses_to_flag: Well-rounded but not distinguished in any area
Activities chosen for resume building rather than genuine interest
Generic essays without authentic voice or specific examples
Lack of depth in extracurriculars (too many shallow involvements)
Missing clear narrative or story arc in application
Not demonstrating specific fit with university
Weak or generic letters of recommendation
No evidence of initiative, impact, or leadership
red_flags_that_predict_rejection: Below 25th percentile test scores without compelling story
No academic rigor or course challenge
Disciplinary issues without context or growth
Activities list that doesn't match narrative
Letters of recommendation that are lukewarm or template-based
No demonstrated interest or understanding of university
Application feels assembled rather than authentic
